title: Executive
description: You have a natural ability to lead and make decisions. You thrive in high-pressure environments and enjoy taking charge of projects and people.
detailedDescription: You're an organized go-getter who's interested in the business side of health care. The idea of planning, directing, and coordinating medical and health services intrigues you. Adapting to an ever-changing landscape of health care laws, regulations, and technology doesn't phase you. You may already have a background in business or health care and find yourself ready for the responsibilities of management.

tabs.title: Motivation
tabs.content: The Executive may like to develop plans and communicate them to a team. They enjoy helping others do their best at work.

tabs.title: Skills
tabs.content: This role is skilled at leading and communicating with others. They have good attention to detail and enjoy analyzing information and using technology.

tabs.title: Works With
tabs.content: Careers in The Executive's path often involve working with health care providers and managing staff or finances.

tabs.title: Courses
tabs.content: The Executive may have taken college courses in accounting, administration, ethics, or economics.

tabs.title: Setting
tabs.content: A hospital or physician's office are common workplaces for The Executive, although they may also work in a residential care facility or government agency.

tabs.title: Education
tabs.content: Many jobs in this field require college courses in things like accounting, administration, ethics, or economics. Some roles require a bachelor's or master's degree.

tabs.title: Experience
tabs.content: People with experience in an administrative or clinical role tend to be a good fit for this The Executive's career path.

degreeTabs.title: Master's
degreeTabs.content:
If you do have a bachelor’s degree and some work experience, an MBA in Healthcare Management is a smart next step. This MBA concentration will use a health care lens to give you a broad overview of business ethics, law, leadership, accounting, marketing, budgeting, and planning.

Colleges and universities have different names for their programs, so your preferred institution might call the degree by a different name—just look for a description that includes both health care and business.

degreeTabs.title: Bachelor's
degreeTabs.content:
If you don’t already have a bachelor’s degree, many universities offer a Bachelor’s in Health Administration. You can often earn these degrees online in an accelerated format.

Colleges and universities have different names for their programs, so your preferred institution might call the degree by a different name—just look for a description that includes both health care and business.
